search_result.title: Sanders, Clinton announce Wilmington campaign rallies
search_result.text:
Karl Baker

The News Journal

Presidential candidates Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton have announced Delaware campaign stops.

Delaware is holding its primary election on Tuesday.

Sanders is expected to hold a rally Saturday and Clinton is planning a Monday event.

The Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders presidential campaigns each announced Friday the candidates will be appearing in Delaware in advance of the Tuesday primary.

Sanders, a U.S. senator from Vermont, will hold a rally at The Chase Center on the Riverfront, 815 Justin St., at 1 p.m Saturday, it was announced Friday morning.

The Clinton campaign late Friday announced she will hold a rally at the World Cafe Live at the Queen, 500 N. Market St, at 11:15 a.m. Monday.

Both events are free and open to the public.

Hirak Mukhopadhyaya, president of the University of Delaware College Democrats, said that the competitive nature of the of the national race has likely convinced the candidates to visit Delaware — a rare move for presidential contenders at this stage in the primary.

Mukhopadhyaya said he was initially surprised when he learned of Sanders' visit, but noted that campaign has had a goal to visit many less-populated areas. Clinton's choice to come to Delaware, he said, might have been a reaction to Sanders' decision.

"It's in the candidate's best interest to win the whole mid-Atlantic," Mukhopadhyaya said, who declined to comment on his own candidate preference. "So the whole region is one color."

Connecticut, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island are also all holding their primaries Tuesday, in the final sprint to the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia in July. Sanders on Saturday also is scheduled to campaign in Baltimore, and Clinton appeared in Pennsylvania on Friday.

Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, co-founders of Ben and Jerry's Ice Cream, also campaigned for Sanders on Tuesday in Wilmington, and former Philadelphia Mayor Michael Nutter canvassed for Clinton earlier this month.

The tight nature of the race has made Delaware, which generally gets limited attention during the candidate selection process, a critical state in amassing delegates. In February 2008, then-U.S. Sen. Barack Obama held a campaign rally in Wilmington's Rodney Square, which drew an estimated 10,000 people.

This cycle, Clinton is leading in the Democratic contest with 1,428 pledged delegates. Delaware has 21 pledged delegates that will be awarded proportionally to Democratic candidates based upon the results of Tuesday's primary.

STORY: Trump's diehard supporters wait for Harrington rally

STORY: Half of Delaware superdelegates committed to Clinton

State Democratic Party Chairman John D. Daniello said the party is not working with either the Sanders or Clinton campaigns, but he noted that the competitive Democratic race has been less vitriolic and more focused on policy than the Republican race.

"You should watch how our candidates handle each other versus the other side," he said.

During a campaign event Thursday, Sanders cited favorable comments from Vice President Joe Biden that stopped short of an endorsement of his campaign. Biden told The New York Times he prefers Sanders' "aspirational approach" to rival Hillary Clinton's "caution."

STORY: Delaware role grows larger in primary season

STORY: Ben and Jerry call for Sanders support with ice cream

Sanders told a crowd at the Philadelphia Expo Center in Oaks, Pennsylvania, that he thinks "the vice president is exactly right."

But earlier this month, Biden also stated that he "would like to see a woman elected," an apparent nod to Clinton.

A primary poll by Gravis Marketing of Delaware voters said Clinton was the preferred candidate for 45 percent of those polled, with Sanders at 38 percent, and 17 percent of undecided.

The poll showed Donald Trump, who campaigned in Harrington on Friday, with a 37-point lead over Ohio Gov. John Kasich.

search_result.title: Villanova has won 10 of 11 in Battle of the Blue rivalry with Delaware
search_result.text:
Delaware and Villanova began awarding a trophy to the winner of their annual football skirmish in 2007, branding it the Battle of the Blue.

Every year since except one, Villanova walked off the field with that trophy.

Delaware just got a case of the blues.

Villanova’s dominance of the Blue Hens in their football rivalry has been at times excruciating, mystifying and just plain frustrating for Delaware, which has lost five straight and 10 of 11 in a series that now consists of 50 games.

That has allowed Villanova to zoom ahead 28-21-1 going into Saturday’s latest edition, which kicks off at 1 p.m. at Villanova Stadium.

It was there on Sept. 19 two years ago that Delaware defensive lineman Grant Roberts forced and recovered a fumble by running back Gary Underwood at the UD 21-yard line with Delaware protecting a late 21-20 edge.

“I stripped it and just picked it up and laid it down,” Roberts, the senior out of Concord High, said this week.

But, this being Delaware-Villanova, that wasn’t the end of it for the cursed Hens.

“They [the officials] said his forward progress was stopped,” Roberts added.

TV replays indicated otherwise, that Delaware likely should have kept possession.

On the next play, Villanova quarterback Zach Bednarczyk, then a red-shirt freshman who came on when All-American John Robertson hurt his knee, galloped 21 yards for a touchdown, then ran for a two-point conversion and a 28-21 lead with 2:35 remaining. That would be the final score.

The game had been moved to September from its traditional season-ending spot due to schedule conflicts created because of the pope’s visit to Philadelphia.

Considering Delaware’s misfortune, some wondered if higher forces were at work on the Catholic school campus that sunny afternoon.

No Delaware players have ever experienced the thrill of a win over Villanova, a major motivator, especially for seniors such as Roberts.

“Regardless of the situation, just to beat them would be gratifying,” Roberts said.

The “situation” to which Roberts referred was the NCAA Tournament and the wonderful bonus perhaps awaiting the Blue Hens.

With a win, Delaware (7-3 overall, 5-2 CAA) has a good chance to find itself in the FCS 24-team bracket when it is announced Sunday at 11 a.m. on ESPNU.

“I recognize the significance of playing in a rivalry game like this one,” said first-year Delaware coach Danny Rocco, who was 3-1 against Villanova as Richmond coach the previous five years.

“I recognize the reality that we have not had a lot of success of late but we are very highly motivated to go up there and play a complete game and find a way to come out of there with a win. I’m excited for the challenge.”

Which brings another painful Villanova memory to mind for Blue Hens.

The last time Delaware was positioned to make the playoffs was 2013. It took a 7-4 record into its meeting with the Wildcats, that year at PPL Park (now Talen Energy Stadium), home of the Philadelphia Union in Chester.

It was a disaster.

Ahead 34-12 with less than nine minutes left, Delaware lost 35-34 after a startling array of offensive failure, defensive incompetence, and special teams mishaps. Villanova scored 23 points in the final 8:01, winning on a 24-yard field goal with :01 left after recovering an onside kick.

The 22-point fourth-quarter lead remains the largest Delaware has blown in its 126-year football history.

“It’s just one of those rivalries that brings out sometimes the best and worst in both teams,” Villanova coach Andy Talley, who retired last year, had said after dealing Delaware that devastating defeat.

Delaware discovered the “worst” half of that equation.

But Delaware also lost to Villanova in 2007 and 2010, seasons it reached FCS title games.

In other seasons in which Delaware may have appeared overmatched, it did put up a good fight but fell in heartbreaking fashion. In addition to the 2013 and 2015 games, four more of Delaware’s 10 recent losses to the Wildcats have been by seven points or fewer.

In 2014 at Delaware Stadium, for instance, Villanova needed Robertson’s 21-yard pass to Kevin Gulyas with 23 seconds left and a subsequent two-point pass to overcome a one-point deficit in a 35-28 win. The Wildcats marched on to the FCS quarterfinals.

Delaware’s only win in the last 11 games came in 2011, a 26-16 verdict in Chester against a 2-9 Villanova squad.

While Villanova (4-6, 2-5) is stuck with its first losing record since, “You can’t take the bait,” Rocco said, meaning every CAA game is a challenge.

In addition, the Wildcats remain a significant threat despite injuries that have knocked out key players such as Bednarczyk, tight end Ryan Bell, running back Matt Gudzak and safety Rob Rolle, the CAA preseason defensive player of the year, among others.

Delaware has also lost three defensive starters itself to season-ending injuries – All-CAA linebacker Charles Bell, cornerback Justin Watson and defensive end Cam Kitchen – plus offensive tackle Jethro Pepe.

“I think it’s a typical rivalry game,” said Mark Ferrante, in his first year as Villanova head coach after 30 years as an assistant there.

“You play these games and everyone always says, and we say it to our players and I’m sure coach Rocco will have those guys ready to rock and roll, but you throw the records out the window when you play these games. You just gotta go out and play as consistently as you can and a lot of times it comes down to big plays.”

On Saturday, the Blue Hens will see if they can make the big plays at the opportune moments.

If they do and it earns them that trophy, Delaware can maybe stop singing the FCS Tournament blues, too.

search_result.text:
Last year, when she graduated from Dover High School, Hailey Foster hid a rainbow LGBT pride flag in her gown to unveil at the ceremony, despite being discouraged to do so by school officials.

"I had to represent myself," she said Saturday morning, as her fellow LGBT Delawareans and their supporters marched past her, showering her in rainbow stickers and bracelets during the Delaware Pride Festival's first Pride Parade.

She and Geena Handy, of Camden, said they were pumped for the parade, which kicked off this year's festival in Dover.

"I'm here to be openly gay and have no one shame me for it," Handy said, affixing a sticker to her cheek.

Organizers moved the festival from August to June this year, to coincide with national Pride Month celebrations and the 50th anniversary of the 1969 Stonewall riots.

LGBT Pride Month brings concerts, festivals and new ‘Pride Parade’ to Delaware

Thirty-eight groups marched in the parade, from Delmarva Power to community centers to roller derby teams, according to Delaware Pride president Steve Newman. They made their way through downtown Dover to the statehouse, with festival attendees gathering along the route.

The Pride Festival held its first event in Wilmington in 1998, with a few hundred attendees, Newman said. It's moved to Rehoboth Beach and Dover and now attracts thousands.

Newman said it's important for LGBT people to maintain visibility amid government actions regarding LGBT issues.

The ongoing debate over rights can be seen in the Justice Department's recent efforts to roll back policies protecting workers from being fired for their gender identity or sexual orientation.

Former Dover councilman arrested after hitting Pride Parade organizer with car, police say

"It's fun to do the parade, and it shows people that we're just like everybody else," said Marcia Kratz, a member of Rehoboth TransLiance, a social group for transgender and gender-nonconforming people.

Youth groups had a strong presence at the parade.

John Eichler, a Dover High senior, said he started the school's Gay-Straight Alliance club two years ago. About a dozen of his classmates marched with him on Saturday.

"I'm so happy to be here; it's historic for Delaware," Eichler said.

Behind him, the festive drums and chants of the Essence Legacy Drill Team brought up the rear of the parade. The team, a program of the Walnut Street YMCA in Wilmington, drew cheers from the crowd.

Director Wes-Lay Favors said the parade was a way to expose Wilmington youth to a diverse crowd.

"Whether you're part of the community or an ally, it's a great experience," she said.

As the team began to dance in the street, they were joined impromptu by Rehoboth Beach drag queen Ivy Blue Austin. The drums, Austin said, were hard to resist: "They're calling my name."

search_result.title: Physician-assisted suicide is not the answer to better end-of life care
search_result.text:
Dr. Prayus Tailor

In the discussion about physician assisted suicide, we can learn from the data in other states and other countries. And, we should learn from initiatives and workgroups right here in Delaware.

Nationally, the number of patients who seek physician assisted suicide remains extremely small. Furthermore, many of the patients who seek and are approved for this controversial prescription, ultimately do not take the lethal dose of medication.

So we would ask, what is the true reason why patients resort to this option?

The answer in the large majority of these cases is that patients have lost their autonomy and sense of empowerment in the late stages of their illnesses. Pain, both physical and mental, may be inadequately treated. However, providing a prescription for suicide is certainly not how we should be empowering our patients at the end of life.

Today, Delaware has created many pathways to restore the autonomy of the patient and manage suffering at the end of life. Palliative care and hospice programs are present at almost all hospitals and it’s available in the outpatient setting. Hospitals here in Delaware have launched training programs in adult and pediatric palliative care that will produce doctors with the expertise needed to alleviate suffering and continue the role as physicians as healers and not those who hasten death by assisting in suicide or foster euthanasia.

The recent recognition of DMOST, Delaware Medical Orders for Scope of Treatment, by our state provides a platform for doctors to have important conversations about end of life care and to make sure patient’s wishes are followed. A responsible exception in the new opiate prescribing regulations and the provision of medical marijuana for managing cancer pain also allow pathways for better pain control. Delaware continues to work on ramping up mental health services in our state to provide counseling and treatment for the depression and anxiety that can often compound suffering.

In November of 2015, the Delaware Health Care Commission (DHCC) convened an End of Life Workgroup, of which the primary sponsor of HB 160 was a member. In their final report published in May of 2016 they embrace promoting and advancing DMOST as well as other insightful recommendations. It is important to note that legalizing physician assisted suicide or any form of euthanasia is NOT included in their recommendations.

The key recommendations outlined in the report include the following:

Formally link current activities related to end-of-life and palliative care with ongoing health system transformation efforts involving, at minimum, the Delaware End of Life Coalition, Palliative Care Council of the Delaware Healthcare Association (DHA), the Delaware Health Care Commission (HCC) and the Delaware Center for Health Innovation (DCHI).

Develop, implement and evaluate a Delaware-specific awareness campaign that engages an array of stakeholders and leverages the wealth of available resources in the state. An effective campaign will ideally include standardized materials and information geared toward a variety of audiences (patients, providers, caregivers, etc.), utilize technology and multiple platforms and be culturally sensitive.

Specifically promote palliative and end-of-life care educational offerings as a means to meet continuing education requirements for providers at all levels.

Support and monitor the growth of palliative and end-of-life care services offered in inpatient and community-based settings.

Using resources compiled by the Delaware End of Life Coalition as a basis, build and continue to update a compendium of resources related to end-of-life and palliative care for consumers, advocates, and service providers.

Explore mechanisms to make patient wishes readily accessible in a variety of settings.

Using existing data and data collection tools as a foundation, develop and implement a comprehensive, statewide approach to gathering and using data related to end-of-life and palliative care

We clearly have more work to do. It is critical that the medical profession redouble its efforts to ensure that dying patients are provided optimal treatment for their pain and other discomfort. The use of more aggressive comfort care measures, including greater reliance on hospice care and palliative care, can alleviate the physical and emotional suffering that dying patients experience.

Evaluation and treatment by a health professional with expertise in the psychiatric aspects of terminal illness can often alleviate the suffering that leads a patient to desire assisted suicide. All health care providers must resist the natural tendency to withdraw physically and emotionally from their terminally ill patients. When the treatment goals for a patient in the end stages of a terminal illness shift from curative efforts to comfort care, the level of physician involvement in the patient's care should in no way decrease.

Requests for physician assisted suicide should be a signal to the physician that the patient's needs are unmet and further evaluation to identify the elements contributing to the patient's suffering is necessary. Multidisciplinary intervention, including specialty consultation, pastoral care, family counseling and other modalities, should be sought as clinically indicated. Further efforts to educate physicians about advanced pain management techniques, both at the undergraduate and graduate levels, are necessary to overcome any shortcomings in this area.

It is for these reasons, The Medical Society of Delaware, after careful and thoughtful review of HB 160, strongly oppose any bill to legalize physician-assisted suicide or euthanasia and urge the members of the General Assembly to focus on the recommendations established by the DHCC End of Life Workgroup.

Dr. Prayus Tailor is president of the Medical Society of Delaware.

search_result.title: $45 million later: I-495 bridge closure impact still felt
search_result.text:
Jeff Montgomery

The News Journal

May 29 marks a year since I-495 columns were found to be tipping.

The crossing over the Christina River was closed for repairs.

It was found that 55%2C000 tons of dirt piled nearby caused the issues.

Detours caused extensive delays across the region.

Fallout from the closure of I-495 over the Christina River still is being felt in the form of pockmarked roads, legal disputes and sagging profits, a year after it was discovered pillars supporting the crossing were dangerously tipping.

"We were ready to almost close our doors last year," said Les Tronzo, owner of Sports Car Tire Co. on East 13th Street in Wilmington, which was cut off from traffic for weeks during the detour and $45 million construction project. "We're back somewhat in the black, but we're still trying to make up for last year."

Friday marks a year since senior engineer R. David Charles of the Pike Creek firm Duffield Associates was visiting a job site on the Christina River and happened to notice that several I-495 pillars seemed to be tilting. He sent photos to the Delaware Department of Transportation, which ordered a complete shutdown June 2.

The closure between Exits 2 and 3 cut off a key bypass for the East Coast transportation grid, funneling motorists onto detours across nearby roads and causing a far-reaching impact on the interstate network. U.S. Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx called the stoppage "a national issue" and the Federal Highway Administration stepped in with $2 million in emergency funds.

President Barack Obama later delivered a speech about infrastructure funding at the Port of Wilmington, within sight of the span.

It was later determined that DelDOT had been notified of the column issues weeks before, and that problems were caused after a contractor had deposited 55,000 tons of dirt near pillars. The shifting earth broke and bent underground supports, slowly tipping piers and both the north and south lanes.

Southbound traffic was rerouted for 60 days as crews worked on repairs. Northbound lanes, which had more serious damage, were rerouted for 83 days. The delays sent commute times skyrocketing.

Margaret Garrison of Newark said it was like rush hour all day. She travels the region for a service that provides medical checks for insurance customers.

"If I had to go up into north Wilmington, I had to plan on an hour drive, versus half an hour," she said.

Herbert Bollman, owner of the F&H Transport truck shop off I-495 and Terminal Avenue, estimates his business was sliced by 20-25 percent because of the closure. The drop in port-related traffic and motorists using I-95 as an alternate hurt, he said.

"When they shut the bridge down, we lost our customers that normally come from Pennsylvania going south immediately," Bollman said.

Truck drivers were upset over lost time, increased fuel costs and inconvenience, he said.

Wilmington resident Howard Laws, whose Eden Park neighborhood is near the I-495 overpass, recalls days of traffic, noise and exhaust surging along New Castle Avenue and nearby streets.

"It caused a lot of road damage, a lot of traffic jam, a lot of commotion," Laws said. "I won't even talk about the pollution that it caused."

DelDOT sees lessons learned in case

Barry Benton, the state Transportation Department chief bridge engineer, said they were very aware of traffic disruptions and the potential economic impact, especially in summertime.

Within days of the shutdown, DelDOT announced plans to shore up the underside of the bridge and repair supports while traffic moved above, instead of building a replacement. The agency launched what would become a massive, on-the-fly fix that would pull in contractors and supplies from around the country.

Engineers also opted for solutions that in hindsight might have been more massive than needed, including huge concrete bases for two damaged sets of piers, Benton said. They also had to comply with federal preferences for design choices.

"We were making some conservative, quick assumptions," he said. "In order to move forward, we were designing it while we were getting information. The [cost of] materials weren't that big a deal, compared to the user costs of what was happening on I-95."

At one point, workers cut holes in the bridge deck so 160-foot steel cages could be lowered in one piece into 4-foot holes drilled under the span, then filled with cement to create a stable base for new supports.

Contractors also were skeptical about drilling 150-foot-deep holes for supports under a bridge with far less clearance. Two drilling companies backed out after examining the challenge.

Port Director Gene Bailey said DelDOT managed to complete the repairs before peak operations resumed, a time when as many as 1,500 vehicles would have been moving in and out of the port gates daily. Only a between-season fruit shipping fall-off prevented the problem from being worse, he said.

"Sometimes you'd rather be lucky than good," Bailey said.

Benton said the experience was a lesson for the agency. He said they adopted reforms to address safety and supervisory shortcomings, and recently shared what was learned at a recent meeting of bridge engineers from all 50 states.

"We explained what we went through, how we fixed it and let them know how processes changed at DelDOT and what they should look at as well," he said.

DelDOT will present a paper on the issue next month at an international conference in Pittsburgh, long known as the "City of Bridges."

Benton said the agency also addressed why the original notification fell on deaf ears. In April 2014, Charles Allen Jr. of Elkton, Maryland, called DelDOT and 911 with worries that the bridge lanes were out of kilter. He uses the crossing to get to his auto body shop in Wilmington.

"I'm just a little concerned," Allen told the DelDOT official, according to a recording. "I mean, it doesn't look right."

Allen's warning and other hints of trouble were treated with skepticism and dismissed. Another call on May 30 also generated no action. An October 2012 inspection of the bridge, built in 1974, found it was in "good condition."

Allen said this week he was satisfied by assurances that DelDOT has improved its reporting system, assuring that hazard calls are taken seriously. But he also said the incident has been "blown out of proportion" by some.

"What kind of aggravates me is, they're saying this is an infrastructure problem, a national big deal," Allen said. "It's a repair. Somebody made a mistake, dumped some dirt and they need to get it resolved."

Charles, the engineer who got a response from DelDOT, credited the agency and contractors with coming up with a smart solution.

"I think it was a great project, an interesting project," he said. "I wish I could have worked on it."

In a twist, Charles said that he worked on a soil-instability project 30 years ago on the north side of the Christina River, after an earthen berm that was enlarged by the Corps of Engineers shifted surrounding ground several feet, affecting utilities.

The Delaware Engineering Society in February named Charles the Delaware Engineer of the Year for spotting the problem. He said Allen deserved credit as well.

Case may still go to court

Negotiations continue between state attorneys and the intertwined businesses associated with the dirt pile: Alma Properties LLC, Port Contractors Inc. and Keogh Contracting Co.

The land is owned by DuPont Co., which leases it to Port Contractors. That firm has an agreement to let Keogh use the property for storage and also has an interest in Alma, which owns land near the site.

Keogh is owned by James B. Thomas Jr., son of a founder of Port Contractors. Thomas did not return a call for this story, but said in June that "I feel very badly about what happened to the bridge."

His father, James Thomas Sr., last month said the companies "know they have a fight on their hands" because of the government lawsuit threats.

DelDOT has hired a national legal firm to represent the agency in negotiations and possibly in court.

Laws, the Eden Park resident, said someone should have noticed the pile of dirt and raised concerns.

"This is what happens in life when you think you can't do any damage," he said. "It's just amazing how the city and county can come and do code enforcement, but never look at stuff like that."

Wilmington has yet to recover from what started a year ago, Tronzo said.

"The roads in the city weren't designed to take the kind of traffic they were getting when tractor-trailers were diverting straight up through," he said. "They still haven't fixed the potholes and damage to the curbs from the tractor-trailers."

search_result.title: Police release part of 911 tape in wheelchair shooting
search_result.text:
Jessica Masulli Reyes, Jenna Pizzi, and Brittany Horn

Investigators from the Delaware Department of Justice and Wilmington police are continuing to piece together what led four officers – three white and one Hispanic – to shoot to death a black man in a wheelchair on Wednesday.

City police say Jeremy “Bam” McDole was armed and reaching for a gun when the officers opened fire, but McDole’s family has denied he had a gun, pointing to a cell phone video posted to YouTube where one is not visible.

McDole, 28, was killed in the 1800 block of Tulip Street after the four officers shot him several times. City officials have not identified the officers, but confirmed their races on Friday. All remain on administrative leave.

Late Friday, police released a portion of the 911 call. In it, a woman says a man shot himself and they needed to get an ambulance to the AutoZone parking lot along Lancaster Avenue.

Police spokeswoman Andrea Janvier said the audio was released “in the interest of preserving public safety and to address the specific question of whether Mr. McDole was armed at the time of the incident.” The remainder of the call will not be released at this time, she said.

The News Journal/delawareonline exclusive audio:

The female caller says to “send (police) quick” to Autozone and South Scott Street. She repeatedly says McDole, who is not yet identified, is moving but that he shot himself and he still has a gun.

“Please get the cops here,” the woman in the 911 audio says.

She says she doesn’t know where his weapon is but she repeatedly asks for police response, saying he has a weapon in his hand. She says he shot himself and the emergency dispatcher asks her to move back from the situation.

She says she doesn’t want to move closer to him and to “please get the cops here” and confirms he’s in a wheelchair. She repeatedly says he has a weapon in his hand, telling others nearby to back up from the scene.

McDole’s family members have maintained that he did not have a weapon. Family members could not be reached late Friday night.

But Pastor Derrick Johnson of Joshua Harvest Church said witnesses at the scene prior to the shooting told him McDole had a gun.

While Johnson has not led any of the protests following the shooting, he said the issue is not simply whether McDole was armed.

“The issue is the actions of police as clearly displayed on the video,” he said, referring to a phone video of the police confrontation shot by a bystander.

“If they knew he had a gun and that they were dealing with a person who was suicidal, why wasn’t a psychologist ... or someone like that sent with them to talk him down,” he asked.

The official investigation of the shooting continued on Friday, though few details were released.

At least six investigators from Attorney General Matt Denn’s office were at the scene Friday, two of whom examined a shed in the parking lot of a gas station that backs up to the corner of Tulip and South Lincoln streets. Other investigators focused further down the street.

As the investigators searched, a makeshift memorial stood on the spot of the shooting, marked by yellow cones that have “bam” and “rip” scrawled on them. The cones, which occasionally get knocked down by the wind, are surrounded by candles, beer cans, stuffed animals, flowers and balloons.

News of the shooting has garnered international attention – topping CNN and other media’s homepages on Friday. Despite the attention, few details have been released.

Janvier declined Friday to answer questions, including ones about the number of shots fired, what preceded what is seen on the video, and the officers’ names.

Depending on how the investigation progresses over the weekend, the department may be able to provide more information on Monday, she said.

Robert Bovell, a Hilltop resident who has been with the family since the shooting, said he and McDole’s family are upset that city police haven’t given more details.

“We are all unhappy,” Bovell said. “We just want to examine the facts of what happened.”

Much of the public information about the shooting has come from a cellphone video that shows one officer pointing a shotgun at McDole, screaming at him to “drop the gun.” Other officers are later heard screaming, “Hands up.”

McDole, who is paralyzed from the waist down, fidgets, moving his legs with his hands and rubbing his knees with both hands, and tries to raise himself out of the wheelchair. He is then seen sliding his hand up his thigh and toward his waist as officers open fire.

WARNING: Graphic video

Police have said they responded to a 911 call at 3 p.m. Wednesday about a man with a self-inflicted wound who was armed. The chief said police found a .38-caliber gun at McDole’s side after the shooting.

Officials have assured the public that their investigations are ongoing.

The Department of Justice’s Office of Civil Rights and Public Trust is conducting its investigation separate from the Wilmington police, as is standard after a police shooting.

The office, which has two attorneys and three investigators, was created within the Department of Justice after Denn took office earlier this year.

“The Office of Civil Rights and Public Trust conducts investigations of police shooting incidents in order to determine whether the officer or officers were in compliance with Delaware law,” spokesman Carl Kanefsky said. “That determination, which could result in criminal charges, is made solely within the Attorney General’s Office.”

Kanefsky said investigators work both separately and with the police agency after a police-involved shooting.

Latest shooting intensifies scrutiny of police conduct

The police department and Department of Justice will both respond to the scene, observe the autopsy and observe interviews. Other activities, however, are done separately, such as seeking and interviewing witnesses, examining the scene and reviewing evidence.

The results will be released publicly and posted to the Department of Justice website when they are complete, he said. These investigations can often take several months to finish.

The Department of Justice took more than six months to clear the Wilmington officers who shot Marvin T. Jones, a Georgia man paralyzed by police during a traffic stop on Vandever Avenue in January.

Neither Wilmington Police nor the Department of Justice have released details about what led up to and followed Wednesday’s shooting.

Jon Shane, a retired captain from the Newark Police Department and associate professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, said it appears the officers involved in McDole’s death were justified in their use of force, because they believed at the moment that he was armed and that he was able to use the gun because of the 911 call that he had shot himself.

“The less information officers have, they have the right to draw some inferences,” Shane said. “They treat every gun as loaded until they find out it is not, and every gun as real until they find out it is fake.”

Family disputes police, says McDole had no gun

Shane said the video raises many questions about the incident, but said if the matter goes to court, the officers will likely be able to prove that use of force was justified.

“The law is pretty clear on how you can use force,” Shane said. “You have to be in fear for your life or for the life of a third person and you have to be able to articulate what those fears are.”

Shane said the officers, because of their training or because they have a different vantage point than seen in the bystander video, may have seen something different that presented a real threat.

“These things are always delicate,” Shane said. “There are not many police shootings where people believe the police account unless it is so clear – and they never really are.”

Maria Haberfeld, professor and chair of the department of Law, Police Science and Criminal Justice Administration at John Jay College, said officers are trained not to see anyone as less of a threat because of their appearance or disability. Therefore, these officers would not have approached McDole differently than someone not seated in a wheelchair.

“There are plenty of what police call war stories where somebody who appeared to be completely benign or not a threat pulls out a gun or knife and kills an officer,” Haberfeld said. “I’ve seen many departments training use of force around the concept of unusual suspects.”

Haberfeld said it is an ABC of police training to identify the threat no matter if the person is old, young, able-bodied or disabled.

“It is about the final outcome, whether you are 80 years old, 8 years old or in a wheelchair, the outcome is the only consideration here,” Haberfeld said.

Officers are trained to leave distance between themselves and suspects they believe to be dangerous, therefore it would have gone against training to go behind McDole to subdue him.

“Your training is not to be a Kung Fu master and wrestle someone to the ground like that,” Shane said. “You don’t want to put yourself in a situation where you have to use force because you don’t have distance on your side.”

McDole’s mother has said her son did not have a gun. Pastor Ty Johnson, who has been close to the family since the incident, said they continue to hold that belief, despite what police have said.

Johnson said the family, which is making arrangements to bury McDole, is still processing the incident but hopes to look closely and analyze any evidence they can.

“We certainly want to wait and find out,” Johnson said.

McDole’s mother, Phyllis, raised concerns Thursday that she was never notified that her son had been killed or where his body was taken after the incident.

“They never notified me where his body was,” she said. “They have yet to come and tell me anything. I had to call them this morning and find my own child, my own child laying in a morgue.”

Kimberly H. Chandler, a spokeswoman for the Delaware Department of Safety and Homeland Security, said in an email to The News Journal on Friday that autopsies are usually performed the same day as the death or the next day.

“Families do not get to view the body before an exam, unless it is needed for identification purposes only,” she said.

Chandler added that autopsies are performed in any death that is “sudden, unexplained or violent.”

Gov. Jack Markell attended a vigil Thursday night outside McDole’s mother’s home. His office released the following statement Friday:

“I had the opportunity to meet with relatives of Jeremy McDole yesterday, including his mother, grandmother and sister, during the vigil held in his honor and to offer my sincere condolences for their loss. The vigil was peaceful and somber, arranged by a community in mourning. I am grateful the Attorney General’s Office has taken swift action to review the details of the case and await the results of its investigation.”

The family is still working to set up a fund to accept donations to go toward funeral expenses.

The Wilmington Police Department asks that anyone with information about the incident contact Detective Sergeant George Pigford at (302) 576-3674 or George.pigford@cj.state.de.us.

The Department of Justice asks anyone with information about the incident to call Special Investigator Frank Robinson at (302) 577-8707.

search_result.title: The patriarch of Delaware's influential du Pont family has died at 103
search_result.text:
Irénée du Pont Jr., the patriarch of Delaware's prominent, wealthy and influential du Pont family, died Monday. He was 103.

Du Pont was the great-great-grandson of DuPont Co. founder Éleuthère Irénée du Pont de Nemours who fled France for Delaware during the French Revolution and began building a vast family fortune by producing gunpowder along the banks of the Brandywine.

His father Irénée du Pont Sr., along with his father's two brothers Pierre S. du Pont, founder of Longwood Gardens in Kennett Square, and Lammot du Pont had each served as the Wilmington-based DuPont Co.'s president. They helped expand its interests from an explosives manufacturer to one of the world's largest chemical companies.

Irénée du Pont Jr., who had eight sisters, was the youngest and only son of Irénée and Irene Sophie du Pont, who were second cousins.

A graduate of Wilmington's Tower Hill School, he attended Dartmouth College and graduated in 1943 with a degree in mechanical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, his father's and uncles' alma mater.

He was hired by "the family business," as some du Ponts liked to call the DuPont Co., in 1946, by the late DuPont scientist Nathaniel C. Wyeth. Wyeth was the inventor of the plastic soda bottle and the older brother of famed Chadds Ford artist Andrew Wyeth.

As was the family tradition, Irénée Jr., known by his nickname "Brip," worked his way up the company ladder. He learned the ropes and held various engineering and supervisory positions at plants in Arlington, New Jersey; Parkersburg, West Virginia, and Charleston, West Virginia.

He returned to Wilmington in 1953 and later served as the company's senior vice president before retiring in 1978.

Du Pont told The News Journal in a 2000 interview that he declined all suggestions that he run the company.

"I as a stockholder would have objected to me as president," he said.

Du Pont told The News Journal he had dyslexia and it would have kept him from doing the huge volume of reading needed to do the job well. "I would have been a disaster. You've got to be a very astute and quick-witted person to take an executive level of leadership. It would have been in my financial interest not to go there."

Still, du Pont was one of the last family members to reach one of the highest levels of management in the DuPont Co. The family who had led the DuPont Co. for most of the 20th century eventually ended its control in the late 1970s.

Life at Granogue

Du Pont was once considered one of the richest men in the world, according to various Forbes magazine rankings over the years. He brushed aside the reports and told The News Journal the $525 million net worth which Forbes attributed to him and his family in Montchanin in 1998 was based on money "generated generations ago."

When a News Journal reporter interviewed him in 2000, du Pont was more than delighted to show off the tag inside the blazer he was wearing. It wasn't from Brooks Brothers. He bought the jacket at Value City, which, at that time, was a well-known discount store.

He lived at Granogue, the hilltop estate and mansion with a mile-long driveway and 30 rooms in northern New Castle County, which can be seen along points of Smith Bridge Road. It is sometimes referred to as the symbol of Chateau Country, the name for Delaware's most exclusive region and for generations the home of extended members of the du Pont family.

The century-old house was built in 1923 by du Pont's father. The mansion has 11 bedrooms for family members and six for live-in employees. Walls are lined with paintings by family friends, like Maxfield Parrish, and Rembrandt Peale's original painting of DuPont founder Éleuthère Irénée du Pont de Nemours hangs over a hearth.

Du Pont was proud of an oak-paneled music room, home to an Aeolian pipe organ housed in a chamber below the floor. The music is controlled by a computer, much like a player piano, but sometimes du Pont brought in musicians to play the organ. He enjoyed sharing the organ's music with others.

He and his wife Barbara also were known for opening the grounds of their estate to local organizations and groups for fundraisers.

A 5K run and walk called Granogue & Bach were held in the 1990s to raise money for Brandywine Baroque. Musicians played Bach compositions for participants at the finish line. In recent years, the Beau Biden Foundation has hosted trail runs on the estate with more than 800 participants.

President Joe Biden, who attended the run when he was vice president, had raced motorbikes on the estate with Irénée when Biden was serving in the Senate. Biden's sister Valerie once lived on the Granogue property

A passion for car collecting

Du Pont told The News Journal he was a "motorhead" and enjoyed collecting motorcycles and automobiles which he stored in his 12-car garage.

Over the years, his collection included everything from a 1980 two-door Chevette hatchback to a 1936 Oldsmobile coupe his father gave him on his 16th birthday.

He frequently brought his 1918 Cadillac to various events, including Winterthur Museum's annual Point to Point steeplechase races and to the Marshall Steam Museum at Auburn Valley State Park in Yorklyn.

Du Pont found the car at a salvage yard in 1939 when he was a student at Dartmouth College. He said he paid $40 for it and joked he spent as much on immediate repairs. He said the car once was owned by actors Frank Fay and Barbara Stanwyck.

Du Pont was known for upholding his family's legacy and served on DuPont's board of directors until 1990 and worked on various projects as a trustee for Wilmington University and Longwood Gardens, the former home of his Uncle Pierre.

Despite the clannish nature of the family, another tradition du Pont had long upheld was never stepping foot on the Nemours estate of Alfred I. du Pont in Rockwood. It was due to a historic rift that happened a few years after cousins Pierre, Alfred and T. Coleman du Pont banded together to buy the DuPont Co. in 1902. Pierre and Alfred had a falling out about control and Alfred lost his role in the company.

When Alfred built his Nemours estate, he installed a 10-foot stone wall topped with shards of broken glass to surround the majestic mansion inside. Supposedly, he said he built the wall with the glass shards around his estate “to keep out intruders, mainly of the name of du Pont,” according to Marquis James’s 1941 book "Alfred I. duPont: The Family Rebel."

Irénée Jr. told The News Journal in 2000 that his father was on his brother Pierre's side and gave his children strict instructions to never step foot inside the Nemours gates.

Du Pont obeyed for years, but apparently changed his mind, and in 2008 he told The News Journal "it's a great place — if you like that kind of thing."

He was predeceased by his eight older sisters; his daughter, Susanne; his son, Irénée du Pont, III; and Barbara, his wife of 77 years.

Du Pont is survived by his daughter-in-law, Eugenie Collison du Pont, and his daughters Irene Light (Tom) of Lime Rock, Connecticut; Cynthia Tobias (Terry) of Chadds Ford, Pennsylvania; Sally Quinn (Rob) of Winchester, Massachusetts; Grace Engbring (Paul) of Telluride, Colorado; 13 grandchildren, and 13 great-grandchildren.

A memorial service will be held at a later date. Burial will be private.

search_result.title: Iowa caucus: The history of why Iowa is first-in-the-nation
search_result.text:
Five months before the July Democratic National Convention, when there’s still snow on the ground, Iowans traditionally gather across the state in school gymnasiums, community centers and other locations to decide who in their party they support for president.

Some other states don't have their primaries until June, a month before the national convention. So why does Iowa start so early? More importantly, out of all the states, why is Iowa first?

The answer to those questions involves a little bit of pragmatism, a little bit of political conflict, and, these days, a strong desire to stick to tradition.

More: The Democratic Party is planning to reject Iowa's virtual caucus plan. Here's how we got here.

Iowa has almost always held caucuses for presidential selection rather than the primary system used in other states like New Hampshire, which is the second state to vote on presidential picks. But it wasn't always first in the nation.

Roots in the 1960s

After the tumultuous 1968 Democratic convention, the DNC decided it needed to open up its process to lessen the power of party leaders and involve more grassroots activists. That paved the way for the shake-up that led to Iowa moving to first on the calendar.

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Democrats in Iowa said they were frustrated with the state's caucus system, which they felt was run by party bosses and didn't respond to grassroots voices and desires.

Changes to address this problem involved holding separate district and state conventions, which meant that the whole caucus process needed to start earlier.

Kathie Obradovich, the Register's opinion editor, speaking for a video about Iowa's caucus history, says that "the old story is that they figured out how long it would take to print all the paperwork on their elderly mimeograph machine."

So Iowa was first.

When did the caucuses become powerful?

The question remained: Who cared? In 1972, Gary Hart cared. Obradovich recounts the story: "In the 1972 presidential race, Sen. George McGovern’s campaign was managed by a young political whiz kid named Gary Hart. Hart noticed that Iowa was going to be first in the nation and decided to make a bid here as a way to get (McGovern) a media boost before the New Hampshire primary. It worked."

In 1976, Jimmy Carter replicated McGovern's success. The media paid attention to his performance in Iowa, and it illustrated the caucuses as an important metric of a candidate's strength. Carter went on to become president.

But Iowa had to fight for its right to be first

However, this first-in-the-nation status wasn't set in stone.

Prompted by Carter's reelection loss in 1980, the national Democratic Party theorized that the drawn-out nomination process was more of a hindrance than a help to their party's nominee. They rolled out new rules that would restrict how early any state's nomination processes could be held, but still allowed Iowa to caucus first. At that point, it seemed like everyone was happy.

Then, Vermont moved up the date of its straw poll. In response, New Hampshire made its primary earlier. In defiance of the national party, Iowa chose to move the caucuses earlier than its nationally assigned date to maintain the buffer between the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary.

In November of 1983, with the caucuses (whatever their date was to be) soon approaching, state party officials gathered to resolve the disagreement and vote on the official date. Those in favor of the earlier date wanted to preserve both Iowa and New Hampshire's unique roles in the nomination process. Those in favor of the later date wanted the whole process shortened to help the eventual nominee.

The party leaders voted 20-10 for the earlier date. Iowa's status as first in the nation was, at least for the moment, secured.

"Today," Obradovich said, "Iowa caucuses are first-in-the-nation mainly because the state insists on remaining first."

The outsized media attention on Iowa means many candidates build their strategies around the early state, seeing those first votes as a way to give them momentum through other states. Barack Obama credits the Iowa caucuses for giving him the initial momentum that propelled him to the White House.

As long as the state is first, it's seen as the first serious litmus test of a candidate. And as Iowa indicates or influences later success, candidates will keep coming, journalists will keep reporting, and in February, the eyes of the nation will stay on Iowa.

Clare Ulmer is a politics reporter for the Register. Reach her at culmer@registermedia.com or at 515-284-8724.

search_result.title: Retired policeman Paddack ready for Ocean City's big problems on ...
search_result.text:
After serving with the Ocean City Police Department for nearly three decades, Mark Paddack wanted to continue his service in a different capacity.

Following his retirement from OCPD, Paddack ran for Ocean City Town Council and secured one of the three council seats up for election this year.

Paddack received 1,187 votes for Town Council — the second most of the five candidates who ran. He was sworn in to the position Nov. 8.

Delmarva Now spoke with Paddack about his goals as the newest Town Council member and what issues he thinks need to be addressed.

Responses were edited for clarity and brevity.

Continuing to serve the community

What made you decide to run for the Ocean City Town Council?

I've lived in Ocean City my entire 28-year career with OCPD. Back in the mid-1990s, I wanted to run for Town Council, but couldn't because I was a policeman. During my career, people reached out to me and really liked me as a policeman. I'm very involved in community organizations, including the Elks Club, the Delmarva Blood Bank and the Boy Scouts of America.

I retired from OCPD after 28 years. I didn't intend to run for Town Council until 2020. But when Wayne Hartman won his primary race in June, that vacated a seat on the Town Council.

I've only ever wanted to be an elected representative in Ocean City because I believe in Ocean City. It's not about ego. I've served in multiple capacities as a policeman on town committees. I've been involved in many different ways, but the catalyst for me was when Wayne Hartman won the primary. That vacated a seat and solidified to me I should run.

There's a quote from Ann Landers: "Opportunities are usually disguised as hard work, so most people don't recognize them." I believe when we are not successful in life with one endeavor, there will be other opportunities to try again. That's how we become successful leaders in everything we do. So when Wayne vacated that seat, I said, "This is my opportunity to keep serving."

For the last five years, I policed our southern district on bike patrol with all the downtown and Boardwalk businesses. That gave me a good grasp of the street performer issues and ordinances pertaining to the Boardwalk. I know how to solve problems. The Boardwalk has problems every day, and we try to resolve those issues as quickly as we can. Sometimes it means using interpersonal communication skills and educating people. As a council member, I know I can continue to do that.

Focusing on public safety

As the newest Town Council member, what are some of your goals?

My involvement with the Ocean City government is not my first rodeo. I was president of the Fraternal Order of Police for 10 years during a very tumultuous time period. Eventually, I led a referendum to utilize collective bargaining with binding interest arbitration between OCPD and the Town Council. Since then, the five contracts we've negotiated with the town have been amicable and professional.

My goal is to continue the amicable relationship between the council and all the employees, with an emphasis on public safety. The largest portion of the town's budget is public safety — $32 million a year. As a policeman, I've been involved in every special event the town has operated. I bring knowledge of how to make future events productive for the town, while also improving public safety.

I'm a guy who believes in strict enforcement of the law. I don't endorse shutting down any events. I endorse pursuing avenues in which we can strictly enforce the laws to curtail unwanted behavior from outsiders. This is one of my goals for Ocean City's special events.

Another goal of mine is to continue to maintain my character and integrity. You hear all politicians talk about transparency — well, I'm not a politician. I'm a policeman, who's going to say what needs to be said.

Leaving a lasting legacy

What changes or improvements do you think need to be made to the Town Council?

My addition brings 57 years of life experience, taking opportunities and leaving a lasting legacy. In 1994, I wrote two $500,000 grants and co-founded the OCPD bike patrol unit. Today, the entire downtown neighborhood and business district is policed by bicycle.

Another example of my experience is co-founding OCPD's Citizen Police Academy, the longest running open, public dialogue between law enforcement and citizens in Maryland. We've been doing that for 27 years, and it's not going away.

In my community involvement, I served on the Board of Directors for the Caine Woods Community Association for 10 years. Then I purchased a lot and built a home in Caine Keys II. When I moved there, I was immediately nominated president of that association, where I've served for the last 13 years. I have an intricate personal knowledge of community issues. My learning curve is small. It's not my first rodeo, and I've hit the ground running from day one.

Navigating the offshore wind energy issue

What are some important issues you think need to be addressed?

The first issue is the tax differential between the town and the county. We need to come to an agreement that's not so adversarial, but cohesive in achieving our goal. Do I have an answer for this issue? No, I need to learn more about this.

Another issue facing us is the wind farm off the coast of Ocean City. That was done at the federal level and approved by the state. What wasn't approved, though, were the larger wind turbines now proposed. The technology wasn't available years ago when the project was being developed. They've taken what were about 260-foot wind turbines, and they're now proposing up to 600- or 800-foot wind turbines. The line of sight from the shore is going to be inhibited by those wind turbines.

There's also a debate over whether it will either build or destroy the fisheries for recreational and commercial fishermen. Some argue the wind turbines will create reef systems where fish will congregate, while others argue the vibrations from the turbines will drive fish away. That needs to be investigated. I'm a highly trained investigator who looks at things objectively to keep my opinion out of it. When we have the facts, we need to make the right decisions to benefit everyone.

The other issue is with the dualization of Route 90. If the Route 50 bridge goes down, we only have Route 90 and then Coastal Highway up into Delaware, so the dualization of Route 90 can greatly impact the safety of the town during emergency situations.

Helping others

What are you looking forward to most during your time on the Town Council?

I'm looking forward to being able to be me. I like to help people, and I've shown that throughout my career. As a council member, I'm very approachable. I go to a lot of different charitable functions to help generate funds for those who are in need — I've done that my whole career. As a council member, I want to be me. I don't want to be someone I'm not. I'm a leader from one end to the other. I don't ask people to do anything I wouldn't do myself.

search_result.title: Delaware resort hosts international tennis tournament
search_result.text:
Doug Ferrar

dferrar@dmg.gannett.com

Competitors from five different countries came to the Delaware beaches last week when the 2016 INAS Tennis World Championship for Players with Intellectual Disability settled into the Sea Colony Tennis Center in Bethany Beach for a week of high-level international play.

Beginning with an opening ceremony on Sunday, June 12, 24 athletes from the United States, Australia, Belgium, the Czech Republic and Italy dug in for a crowded schedule of singles, doubles and mixed doubles matches played out over the week.

Many of the athletes played all three types of match, alternating throughout the course of each day. Each player had only a 30-minute break between matches, said tournament director Campbell Booth.

The finals matches were played on Saturday, followed by closing and awards ceremonies.

The event was sponsored by INAS, the International Association of Sport, a UK-based organization for elite para-athletes with intellectual disability. The tournament, the first one hosted in the United States, was organized by Athletes Without Limits, the United States member organization of INAS.

Intellectual disability is defined as a neurodevelopmental disorder that impairs mental function and individual functional skills. The condition affects less than 3 percent of the population to varying degrees. AWL founder and president Barry Holman emphasized that the goal of his organization is the development of talent in athletes who might not be adequately served by mainstream programs.

"We look at the athlete first," he said. "And that's why we say athletes with an intellectual disability, not an intellectually disabled athlete. That's how INAS brands it as well. First and foremost, we are a high-performance sports organization. This is high-performance tennis. You would find the top male players would be playing at the level of (NCAA) Division III college tennis."

More than just tennis

Holman founded AWL in 2009, but the tennis program only debuted in 2014, making the first competitive appearance that year at an international championship for players with intellectual disabilities at the Australian Open.

"One of the players from Australia has some offers to play for colleges in the U.S.; he's 19 years old. Also a very fast runner, he holds a 53-second 400 meter record. His name is Josh Holloway," Holman said.

"We have a runner in the U.S., Mikey Brannigan, he will probably break the 4-minute mile this year," said Holman. "The disability affects but doesn't define them, and if they didn't have the disability you would be seeing them on the Olympic stage. And some of them I believe you will be seeing on the Olympic stage."

INAS tennis tournaments use the International Tennis Federation rulebook, with professional judges certified by the United States Tennis Association. With minor accommodation for cognitive and communicative obstacles, play is the same as in mainstream tennis.

"Part of our goal in bringing this event to the United States is to give some exposure to it, so that other tennis families, maybe some tennis clubs and coaches might say, 'Hey, I have an athlete who might fit that eligibility (requirement), but I didn't know this opportunity was out there,'" Holman said.

Australia's Kelly Wren, the undefeated women's tennis champion, supports this goal.

Starting in Special Olympics as an athlete, she quickly came to the attention of the Australian INAS affiliate. After completing her USTA Junior Development track in coaching, she began coaching children's tennis for Special Olympics International. She met Team USA's Brittany Tagliareni at a tournament in Hilton Head, North Carolina.

"I saw the potential in her, and thought, 'This (Athletes Without Limits) is for her,' and that's what I said to Barry, she deserves to be here. He gave her the opportunity and she loves it," Wren said.

RELATED: Shore woman is global messenger for Special Olympics

Wren feels this is an important step for an athlete who is "different," she said. The supportive atmosphere fosters personal development. She cites her high school experience, in which she lacked the self-confidence to know that making mistakes wasn't the end of the world.

"I don't do this for the money, I do it because I enjoy what I do," she said. "You can't sit back. If you sit back, how are you going to know (if you can do it)? That's really the way I see it, and I think I've given Brittany that gift. (Barry) sees the enjoyment, and he can speak to parents and say, 'Hey, we've got something for you now.'"

Team USA coach Jon Sarosiek described the supportive atmosphere and how it encourages the development of these athletes.

"What we're really trying to do this week is make the process about the process and not about results," he said. "Each player has a specific task to accomplish when they play, none of which include making shots or ultimately winning a match. For instance, can we get the doubles team high-fiving between points? We have a player who gets down on herself, can we have her smile between every single point? Results will come if some of these other processes are followed."

With that type of culture promoted within the training, Sarosiek said it has amazing results for the person and the organization as they try to recruit more players.

"It's amazing what that sort of culture promotes for that individual person but also for the organization as we try to grow and to get more people playing," Sarosiek said.

Booth said Sea Colony was chosen as the venue because it is one of the top 50 tennis resorts in the world. A bonus was that nonprofit Athletes Without Limits was not charged for the use of the facility, he said.

BACKGROUND: Sea Colony's tennis director talks about the vision for the program there

Holman praised the way Sea Colony handled the needs of the tournament.

Unexpected downpours on Thursday and Friday threatened to upset the tournament schedule, but the Tennis Center was able to reschedule other activities, allowing the tournament to continue indoors. Getting back on schedule required trimming the number of matches in the semifinals sets on Friday.

ResortQuest, which handles rental arrangements for Sea Colony, provided housing not just for the teams, but also for their families.

Holman said he is looking forward to working with Sea Colony again for future tournaments.

Men's Singles

Gold: Archie Graham, Australia

Silver: Ondrej Sedlisky, Czech Republic

Bronze: Mitchell James, Australia



Women's Singles

Gold: Hanne Lavreysen, Belgium

Silver: Kelly Wren, Australia

Bronze: Brittany Tagliareni, USA

Men's Doubles

Gold: Archie Graham/Damian Phillips, Australia

Silver: Josh Holloway/Mitchell James, Australia

Bronze: Jakob Jerholt/ONdrej Sedlisky, Czech republic

search_result.title: Trump-Clinton too close to call
search_result.text:
Jessica Masulli Reyes

The News Journal

Defying most national polls and surprising many, Republican nominee Donald Trump appeared poised to take the presidency early Wednesday morning, although the count was too close to call.

Results were neck-and-neck for much of election night in key battleground states. Trump secured Florida and North Carolina, while Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton won Colorado and Ohio.

By midnight, election-watchers were still awaiting results in Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, which could propel either Trump or Clinton to victory.

Derek Reigle, a University of Delaware College Republican studying history and political science, said he was "cautiously optimistic" as he watched results pouring in with his father, Hans Reigle, who lost a bid Tuesday for Delaware's lone U.S. Congressional seat.

"He has a chance to be a fantastic president," said Reigle, a first time voter. "I think he has a chance to bring the nation back together in a way Hillary Clinton couldn't."

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

Pike Creek resident Diane Codding, 28, a doctoral student and former teacher, disagreed. As of 11:30 p.m., the Clinton supporter said the results were troubling.

"I'm surprised by the results so far," she said. "They definitely are not what I was expecting."

The margin between the two candidates was thin in the early hours of Wednesday morning.

In Delaware, the election results were more definitive with Clinton garnering about 53 percent of the vote. Trump got about 42 percent, according to unofficial election results from all districts.

Even though Trump lost in Delaware, Rob Arlett, his campaign's state chair, said the vote was strong, more than it had been for a Republican candidate since 1988.

"We are very proud," he said. "I'm not surprised because we've always known that there has been a silent majority that has existed throughout the country and even here in Delaware."

Polls closed at 8 p.m. in Delaware, after being busy, orderly and even somber for most of the day.

The months of campaigning – scarred at times by email scandals and sexual assault commentary and energized other days by messages of hope – came to a quick end, but then dragged on as election results teetered across the nation. Many Delawareans casting their ballots said that end of the campaign cannot come soon enough.

"It's been crazy, I think. Ugly, divisive and we don't have any good choices," 59-year-old Jim Gray said after he cast his ballot as polls opened at Hodgson Vocational-Technical High School in Glasgow.

Gray added that he was looking forward to an end of political commercials.

"I'm tired of the ads," he said.

Millennials could decide presidential race

Unofficial poll watchers won't be allowed inside voting sites

For University of Delaware sophomore Shivam Amin, his first time voting in a presidential election was about choosing the candidate he disliked less.

"To this day, looking at both candidates, I don't even want to vote," he said at A.I. du Pont High School, where Vice President Joe Biden voted.

But national security weighed heavily on his mind. When it came time to send his absentee ballot to New Jersey, Amin, who is Hindu, voted for Trump. He sided with his father who sells furniture, detests Obamacare and hopes a businessman with no political background can get the country back on track.

"Whoever wins there will be riots in the streets," Amin predicted.

Despite the scandals

Most polls leading into Tuesday night showed Clinton with a slight edge over Trump. But faith in those polls wavered Tuesday night as the Trump lead grew.

"Polls are a guesstimation," Arlett said.

"It appears the people are speaking very loud and very clear throughout the country, and people want change."

Both candidates spent the last weeks heavily courting voters in key battleground states. Arlett said he grew tired of the ugliness of the final stretch.

In October, a leaked tape from "Access Hollywood" showed Trump and Billy Bush bragging about sexual assault in 2005. The release caused Trump's numbers to plummet.

Then, Clinton's campaign was hurt after FBI director James Comey announced that the agency would consider additional emails in the investigation against her. Comey told Congress on Sunday that the agency stands by its recommendation not to file charges against Clinton.

These issues weighed heavily on voters in Delaware on Tuesday.

Clinton supporters said she was the most experienced, and ready for the presidency – despite the scandals that peppered her campaign.

"Other people have had similar situations," said Anne Allen, 72 of Bethany Beach. "It's easy to blow things out of proportion and that is what this campaign has been all about, blowing things out of proportion. But America cannot forget about the big issues that got swept under the rug."

Roxann Koren, 63, and Cathy Ferraro, 56, both of Ocean View were in favor of Trump. The women set up a folding card table outside the Roxana Fire Hall in Frankford, and handed out Trump signs, stickers and homemade cake to those who voted for him.

"Trump is going to make our country safe, secure and great again," said Koren.

"And he's not going to let people who are not willing to work hard sponge off the country any longer," added Ferraro. "Trump is going to get people off the streets and back to work."

Some voters left the parking lot feeling indifferent.

Terrie Burns, 43 of Bethany Beach, said she was "embarrassed for everyone."

Voters turnout

Reports from polling locations around the state indicated long lines. About 65 percent of the state turned out to vote, which is consistent with the 2012 race in which President Barack Obama secured his re-election.

Voter traffic was so heavy at Cheswold Fire Hall, a polling station for four election districts, that a town police officer had to be deployed to serve as a crossing guard. About 200 people were lined up when the polling site opened at 7 a.m., according to election workers.

The steady stream of voters heading into the polling site were greeted by state Rep. Trey Paradee, D-Cheswold, and his dog, Teddy. Paradee, who faced a challenge from Republican Janice Gallagher, was joined early Tuesday afternoon by House Majority Leader Valerie Longhurst, D-Bear, who ran unopposed in the General Election.

Emmanuel Chenny, 24, cast his ballot for Clinton at the busy polling station.

"I had some time to look over the candidates so I feel pretty confident," he said. "She has the most experience. She was in the Senate for a good amount of time and was secretary of state."

Chenny said health care was the biggest issue for him.

"I think it's important," he said. "And I want her to continue what President Obama already started."

Chenny, who voted in just his second presidential election, said he believes the nation will be able to get over the division that has defined this election.

"Everything has built up to this point," he said. "But I think we'll be able to get over it just like we do after every election.

Susanne Coggins, 66, said that for her the choice was "simple and clear." The retired elementary school teacher cast her ballot for Trump, saying he identified some important problems that exist in the federal government.

"Hillary is just someone I could never vote for," she said. "She represents the bad guys -- the establishment. We just need a change."

Coggins said she was not concerned by Trump's shoot-from-the-hip rhetoric.

"Did he say some stupid stuff? Yes. Do we all say stupid stuff? Yes," she said. "I think he grew a little like we all do."

On the edge – until the last minute

Deborah Hilyard said she was torn by her choices for president after casting her ballot at the Milton Fire Hall.

"I want to throw up," she said. "I don't know how they allowed those two to be the ones we had to pick from. But what are you going to do? You pick the one you think is going to do the less harm."

Given that criteria, Hilyard settled on Trump.

"I've always registered Democrat, but this year I'm saying no to someone I think is more corrupt than anyone and has no right to be in that office," she said, adding that she voted a straight Republican ticket because she wants to get a "new breeze coming in."

"I'm sick of Hillary Clinton spewing all that ilk," she said. "She's using all that stuff that isn't true and it's been proven that it isn't true. I'm sure Trump is no better, but I haven't seen too much of his commercials that are being dirty against Clinton. He's just stating facts."

Cathy Raffle, 70, said she hopes to God she made the right choice by voting for Clinton at Brittingham Elementary.

The retiree said she was a Trump supporter right up until he allegedly mocked a Washington Post reporter who has arthrogryposis, which limits the functioning of his joints.

"I have friends that have disabled children," she said. "That changed my mind."

Raffle said she liked Bill Clinton when he served as president and has faith in Clinton's knowledge of foreign affairs.

"She can't be that bad," she said, adding that she's relieved the election is nearly over. "They're both good candidates. She's been in there so long and Trump might be a great businessman, but does he know anything about politics?"

In Harrington, the site of the big Donald Trump rally earlier this year, most residents seemed to be seeing red, as in Republican red.

Barbara Bullock, who was on her way to Bible study after voting, said she is glad the election is nearly over.

“I can’t wait to see the results. There needs to be changes,” she said. “I’m not a Trump lover because I support (Ted) Cruz, but I can’t do Clinton. Not another one.”

Erwin Rogers, who has lived in town for more than 50 years, was one of the first to cast his ballot when the Harrington Fire Hall opened at 7 a.m. on Tuesday. Known in Harrington as the guy who tools around town on his three-wheel bike, the 72-year-old Rogers was at the fire hall Tuesday.

“I take pride in voting. Everybody should vote,” he said. “I’ve always been a Republican. I definitely voted for Donald Trump today. He knows what he is doing. If anyone can help this nation be great again, it’s Trump. Hopefully he can bring things back to where they once were.”

Outten said that he hopes there will be a lot of surprises in a state that has historically been Democratic.

“I think you’ll see more seats taken by Republicans in this election,” Outten said. “We’re looking for some surprises today.”

New voters fired up

Voting was a new experience for some Tuesday, whether they were coming of age or have just become citizens.

First time voter, Varyan Thomas, called the entire process a "roller coaster."

"It's kind of nerve-racking for being a first time voter," Thomas said as he left the Elsemere Fire Company where he voted Tuesday morning. "I was like 'I don't want to vote for the wrong person.' "

The 18-year-old Elsmere resident said he was undecided until a couple of weeks ago for who he would be voting for.

In the end, Thomas said "this election was fun."

Compared to other quiet voting places, The Elks Lodge in Dover had a carnival-like feel Tuesday around 11 a.m. when an election official shouted, “We have a first-time voter here,” to the applause of most everyone in the large hall.

Noticeably embarrassed, yet beaming, Didine Cajuste of Dover kept repeating how proud she was to have voted for the first time.

"I’m so excited and so happy right now,” said the Haitian immigrant, who in 2013 became a U.S. citizen. “It’s my time to vote. I was just able to take place in one of the most important American traditions and I am just so proud.”

A few moments earlier, another first-time voter had been recognized. Lischen Toloe of Dover said that she had never taken part in the tradition and was proud of herself for doing so.

“I’ve never felt so proud,” she said as her friend Aaron Nehlar took a photo of her outside the Elks Lodge. “I just exercised my right as an American citizen in a free country for the first time. It was an amazing experience.”

Toloe said now that she had voted, she was going to show people her “I Voted” sticker and make sure they vote, too.

A return to civility

With the election almost over, many voters said they hope the nation can come together once the results are in.

Dianne Miller, 62, brought her daughter Micaela Miller, 21, to Brittingham Elementary in Milton to cast her first ballot in a presidential election. Both women said the choice fore president was clear. They both voted for Clinton.

"I couldn't say I was in love with anyone, but I definitely knew who I wanted to vote for," Micaela said. "Hillary is pro-choice. She for equal rights and equal pay for women. She's defending our democracy by being inclusive of everyone and not turning her back against people who want to come to this country to make a better life for themselves."

Dianne called the current campaign the most contentious of any presidential election she's witnessed, but said she has faith the nation will be able to unite behind the winner.

"I think it's in our history," she said.

Micaela said she thinks it will take time.

"There's too much hate rhetoric going around," the international relations major at University of Delaware said. "I don't think it will go away immediately."

Marvin Phillips, a 44-year-old correctional officer, declined to say which presidential candidate got his vote, although he expressed some concerns that so many of the political signs leading to the polling station were for Trump.

"I wonder why is that," he said. "That probably tells you how I leaned."

Phillips said he's just looking forward to getting the election over with.

"It was just a nasty fight," he said. "No one said what they're going to do as far as changes. To me, it seemed like they were just attacking each other and I don't think that's good for the younger generation coming up to see that."

News Journal reporters Esteban Parra, Scott Goss, Jerry Smith, Margie Fishman, Karl Baker and staff member Karen Okamoto and DelmarvaNow.com staff members Ryan Marshall and Hannah Carroll contributed to this report.

Contact Jessica Masulli Reyes at 302-324-2777, jmreyes@delawareonline.com or Twitter @JessicaMasulli.

search_result.title: Same school, similar achievements, different skin: How race colors ...
search_result.text:
WILMINGTON, Del. – As a kid, Omar Chatt could never wrap his head around why Rosa Parks wasn’t allowed to sit near white passengers on the bus.
